related.description: A number of education trends made their mark in 2013, from massive open online courses to evaluating colleges based on their graduation rates. The underlying forces that drove change this year aren't likely to change anytime soon: declining public funding, changing demographics, advancing technology, and a tough job market.
related.title: 5 Higher-Education Trends for 2014

related.description: American students are bored by math, science and engineering. They buy smartphones and tablets by the millions but don't pursue the skills necessary to build them. Engineers and physicists are often portrayed as clueless geeks on television, and despite the high pay and the importance of such jobs to the country's future, the vast majority of high school graduates don't want to go after them.
related.title: Who Says Math Has to Be Boring?

related.description: When Daquan McGee got accepted to the Borough of Manhattan Community College in the spring of 2010, he was 19 and still finding his footing after a two-year prison sentence for attempted robbery. He signed up for the standard battery of placement tests in reading, writing, and math; took them cold; and failed two-writing and math.
related.title: How to Escape the Community-College Trap

related.description: PALO ALTO - Akshay Kothari's first assignment at the D.school - formally known as the Hasso Plattner Institute of Design at Stanford University - was to rethink how people eat ramen noodles. His last D.school assignment led to a news-reading app that was bought by LinkedIn for $90 million.
related.title: Solving Problems for Real World, Using Design

title: Free Art and Education For All
content:
No one believes in free education more than those who've experienced it. At Cooper Union, one of the the last tuition-free colleges in America, the issue has been especially poignant, since in April board members announced that students will begin paying tuition for the first time in the school's 150-year history. Next year, admitted students will be charged on a need-based sliding scale for that would cap at 50 percent (about $20,000 a year) of the total tuition, but the declaration set off a firestorm of protests and building occupations nonetheless.

For commencement, Cooper Union this year mounted two exhibitons: the official, annual show of student work, , and a response called , organized in by Free Cooper Union, a student group protesting the tuition situation. Show Up included end-of-year exhibitions from students in Irwin S. Chanin School of Architecture, the School of Art, and the Albert Nerken School of Engineering; Step Down -which was organized only a week before-followed the following prompt from Free Cooper Union:

"Students, faculty, alumni, and friends of the Cooper Union are invited to submit works relating to Cooper's hallmarked slogan "Free as Air and Water", as coined by Peter Cooper's son-in-law, Abram Hewitt at Cooper Union's 1901 commencement speech."


Step Down commenced on the Foundation Building's 7th floor and, with lectures, slogans and sitting on the ground, it felt like a remaining bastion of the Occupy Wall Street movement, if no longer free education.

The work of course is plentiful and varied-but as whole very impressive, crossing many media, moods and mindsets. Extant in both shows is art whose existence is not fraught by the deafening pressure of ballooning student debt. How that affects the art is tough to say but it deserves to be considered.

Special nods go to the delightful data visualizations created students at the Albert Nerken School of Engineering. With works that were both beautiful and informative, they tackled such far-ranging topics in infographics as presidential pets, war death tolls and race in the NBA.

Rani Molla has a digital media master's degree from Columbia Journalism School. She's a journalism reader, writer, photographer, videographer, data visualizer and general doer. Follow her on Twitter.
